turn.0: ELI5: How does a computer learn those first few steps of computing?
turn.1: The output from one transistor is strong enough to completely max out the Gate of another.
turn.2: Why was this not possible in analog?
turn.3: Its not *impossible* its just not what its meant to do. Digital isn't "better" than analog, they just do completely different things. You use analog to handle real-world signals that can take a range of values, you use digital to do math and process information. Ultimately, you translate back and forth as needed, like in the case of a monitor taking a digital signal to produce an analog image.
turn.4: So analog has more than 1 and 0? How does that work
turn.5: >Analog devices still use transistors, but they allow for many shades of grey between 0 current an maximum current. Transistors work like switches, with current flowing from the Source to the Drain, controlled by the Gate. This lets a tiny voltage at the Gate control a much larger current, like how a tiny valve can completely shut off a pipe. Analog devices can take a range of voltages through the gate that gradually turns on the current flowing through the device.   Remember, 1 and 0 are just what we call ON and OFF. Its all a matter of how much current is flowing. We get to choose how to interpret that.
turn.8: How do you interpret something that's neither on nor off?
